<::logo: ROVOC Technisch de beste opleider The logo features "ROVOC" in white on a dark background, with the "VC" part incorporating an image of a metal chain and a solid olive-green square.::>

<::An image of a silver refrigerator with its doors open. The upper compartment (fridge) contains several shelves, with items such as a metal bowl, a bunch of green lettuce, and bottles on the door shelves. The lower compartment (freezer) also has drawers and shelves, with some containers visible. The interior is brightly lit. Figuur 1 De koelkast als eenvoudige koelinstallatie : photo::>

<::A cutaway diagram of a refrigerator showing its main components and the refrigerant circulation system. The diagram includes:1. The evaporator coil, located inside the freezer compartment at the top, shown with a box of "ICE CREAM" inside.2. The compressor, a cylindrical unit located at the bottom rear of the refrigerator.3. The condenser coils, a series of vertical tubes running along the exterior back wall of the refrigerator.4. The capillary tube (or expansion valve), a coiled thin tube leading from the condenser to the evaporator.The blue lines illustrate the path of the refrigerant through these components.: diagram::>Figuur 2 Hoofdcomponenten in een koelkast

<::diagram: A refrigeration cycle diagram showing four main components arranged in a circular flow, connected by blue arrows indicating the direction of refrigerant flow. - Top right: Compressor, a black, dome-shaped unit with a motor base. - Top center: Condensor, a black coiled tube with fins. - Middle left: Capillair, a long, thin coiled copper tube. - Bottom center: Verdamper (Evaporator), a grey, rectangular panel with internal serpentine channels. The flow is as follows: 1. From Compressor, a blue arrow points upwards and left, labeled "Hoge druk" (High pressure), leading to the Condensor. 2. From Condensor, a blue arrow points downwards and left, leading to the Capillair. 3. From Capillair, a blue arrow points downwards and right, labeled "Lage druk" (Low pressure), leading to the Verdamper. 4. From Verdamper, a blue arrow points upwards and right, completing the cycle back to the Compressor. Figuur 3 De hoofdcomponenten in een koelkring::>

Toegevoegde energie (warmte) <::schematic diagram: A cooling installation diagram shows a closed loop. At the top, a compressor/pump is fed by "Toegevoegde energie (warmte)" (added energy/heat). From the compressor, a high-pressure gas line passes by a pressure gauge (P) and a thermometer (T), both labeled "hoog" (high) and "gas". This line leads to a condenser (left side), which includes a fan. Below the condenser, blue arrows indicate "Warmteafvoer buiten de koelkast" (heat dissipation outside the refrigerator). From the condenser, a high-pressure liquid line passes a pressure gauge (P) labeled "hoog" and "vloeistof" (liquid), then goes through an expansion valve. After the expansion valve, a low-pressure mixture of liquid and gas passes a pressure gauge (P) labeled "laag" (low) and "vloeistof/gas". This then enters an evaporator (right side), enclosed in a dashed box, which also includes a fan. Below the evaporator, a red arrow points up, indicating "Warmte toevoer in de koelkast" (heat supply in the refrigerator). The low-pressure gas exits the evaporator, passing a pressure gauge (P) and a thermometer (T), both labeled "laag" and "gas", before returning to the compressor.::> Warmteafvoer buiten de koelkast Warmte toevoer in de koelkast Figuur 4 Schematisch weergave koelinstallatie

<::An image of a cold storage room (koelcel) with an evaporator unit mounted on the ceiling. The room is filled with stacks of blue plastic crates containing various fresh produce items, such as fruits and vegetables. Some wooden crates are also visible. The walls are white and ribbed. The room appears to be actively used for storage.: figure::> Figuur 5 Koelcel met verdamper

<::diagram: A 3D isometric diagram illustrating the main components of a refrigeration system for a cold room. The system includes: - A large outdoor condenser unit with six fans, positioned on a rooftop or elevated platform. A red pipe runs from a compressor unit up to the condenser, and a yellow pipe runs from the condenser down towards the cold room. - A compressor unit, depicted as a green machine, located on the ground outside the cold room. It is connected to the condenser by the red pipe and to the evaporator (inside the cold room) by a blue pipe. - A light blue cold room (labeled "KC1" on its orange door), partially enclosed by walls. - An evaporator unit with three fans, mounted inside the cold room. It is connected to the compressor by the blue pipe and to an expansion valve by the yellow pipe. - An expansion valve, a small golden component, located inside the cold room, connecting the yellow pipe from the condenser to the evaporator. The pipes illustrate the flow of refrigerant through the system.::>Hoofdcomponenten van koelinstallatie bij een koelcel

<::A still frame from a video titled "KoeltrainerKoelkring" shows a refrigeration training unit. The unit is mounted on a grey back panel and a table-like base. Key components visible include an outdoor unit with a fan at the top, connected via pipes to an indoor unit (evaporator coil) and a compressor unit at the bottom. There are also pressure gauges, a receiver tank (green cylinder), and what appears to be an electrical control panel. The setup is in a classroom or lab setting with tables and chairs visible in the background. The video player controls are visible at the bottom of the frame, showing 0:00 / 0:58.::>Figuur 8 Opbouw koelinstallatie

<::A diagram illustrating a heat pump system. The main components are labeled A, B, C, and D. At the top, there's a label "Toegevoegde energie (warmte)" (Added energy (heat)) with a red arrow pointing down towards component C. Component C is a compressor. The input line to C (coming from A) has pressure gauge P and temperature gauge T both labeled "laag" (low), indicating "gas" state. The output line from C (going to D) has pressure gauge P and temperature gauge T both labeled "hoog" (high), indicating "gas" state. Component D is a heat exchanger with a fan, labeled 'D'. It receives high pressure, high temperature gas from C. The output from D is labeled "vloeistof" (liquid). Below D, blue arrows point downwards, indicating "Warmteafvoer buiten de warmtepomp" (Heat discharge outside the heat pump). Component B is an expansion valve. It receives "vloeistof" (liquid) from D. Before B, there is a pressure gauge P labeled "hoog" (high). After B, the output is labeled "vloeistof/gas" (liquid/gas mixture), and there is a pressure gauge P labeled "laag" (low). Component A is a heat exchanger with a fan, labeled 'A'. It receives "vloeistof/gas" from B. The output from A is labeled "gas". Below A, black arrows point upwards, and a red arrow points upwards with the label "Warmte toevoer in de warmtepomp" (Heat supply into the heat pump). Component A and the heat supply are enclosed by a dashed box. The overall cycle shows: Warmte toevoer in de warmtepomp (A) -> Compressor (C) -> Warmteafvoer buiten de warmtepomp (D) -> Expansion valve (B) -> Warmte toevoer in de warmtepomp (A). : figure::> Figuur 1

Beschrijving<::A detailed image of a refrigeration training unit, likely used for educational purposes, is displayed. The unit is mounted on a white frame with a blue back panel. Numerous copper pipes connect various components.At the top, there are several digital displays showing numerical values: '10.9', '18.0', '30.9' on the left, and '32.1', '19.9', '19.3' on the right. Below these, two large white rectangular units are visible, likely representing an evaporator and a condenser. The left unit has a label 'Zuiglucht' and 'Retourlucht' with options: 'option Koelen: [x]', 'option Verwarmen: [ ]'. The right unit has a label 'Warmtepomp trainer lucht lucht'.In the center, between the two white units, there are two analog pressure gauges: one with a blue face and a needle pointing to approximately 3 bar, labeled 'Zuigdruk', and another with a red face and a needle pointing to approximately 10 bar, labeled 'Persdruk'. Below these gauges, a small digital display shows '24.7' and '70.4%'.A black compressor unit is located at the bottom center of the setup. Surrounding the compressor are various other components, including a blue cylindrical filter, a black cylindrical accumulator, several valves (some red, some silver), and electrical boxes with indicator lights (green and red). The brand 'Danfoss' is visible on some components. The entire setup is neat and organized, characteristic of a laboratory or training environment. In the background, there's a classroom setting with tables and chairs.Figuur 1 Eenvoudige koelinstallatie::>

<::A photograph of a refrigeration training unit, likely used for educational purposes, mounted on a blue pegboard. The unit features various components connected by copper piping. From left to right, at the top, there are several digital displays showing values such as "18.9", "18.0", "30.9", "32.1", "19.9", and "19.3". Below these displays, there are two large white rectangular panels, representing heat exchangers or similar components. The left panel has small labels in Dutch: "Binnenlucht", "Koudemiddel", "Verwarming", and "Ventilator". The right panel has a label "WARMTEPOMPTRAINER LUCHT LUCHT". In the center, between the two large panels, there are two analog pressure gauges, one with a blue background labeled "Zuigdruk" (Suction pressure) and another with a red background labeled "Persdruk" (Discharge pressure), along with a smaller digital display showing "33.7" and "74.0". Below the panels, a network of copper pipes connects various valves, sensors, and electrical components. At the bottom, a black compressor unit is visible on the left, labeled "Danfoss". To its right are a blue cylindrical component (possibly a filter drier) and a larger black cylindrical component (possibly a receiver or accumulator), all interconnected by the copper tubing. At the very bottom left, a white box with "Coolmark" logo is visible. The background shows a classroom or lab setting with tables and chairs. Figuur 2 Eenvoudige koelinstallatie: photo::>

<::schematic diagram: This diagram illustrates a demo cooling installation (koelen). The system consists of two main loops, likely a refrigeration cycle and a secondary fluid loop, interconnected by a heat exchanger. **Refrigeration Cycle (Black, Green, Blue, Red Lines):** - **Evaporator (E1):** A component with a fan, receiving refrigerant. Temperature sensor TT (T1) is located at its outlet. - **Suction Line:** From E1, a line with pressure sensor PT and temperature sensor TT leads to a compressor. - **Compressor (A1):** A compressor unit with associated sensors: TT (T3), PZH (pressure switch high), PSL (pressure switch low), PI (pressure indicator), and TT (T2). - **Heat Exchanger (H):** A plate-type heat exchanger where the refrigerant (red line input, blue line output) exchanges heat with another fluid (red/blue arrows indicating flow). - **Condenser (B1):** A component with a fan, receiving refrigerant from the heat exchanger. Temperature sensor TT (T4) is at its outlet. - **Liquid Line:** From B1, the refrigerant flows through check valve N1. - **Receiver (D):** A cylindrical tank labeled "0,7 Ltr." for liquid refrigerant storage, connected via valves V1 and V2. - **Filter (C):** A filter component in the liquid line. - **Expansion Device:** A valve controlled by a temperature controller TCE with sensor TT (T5), located before the evaporator E1, indicated by a dashed control line. **Ancillary Components:** - **Valves:** V1, V2, V3, V4 are manual or solenoid valves controlling flow. - **Gauges:** G1 and G2 are pressure gauges/indicators. - **Sight Glass/Filter (F):** A component in the liquid line, possibly a sight glass or filter. - **Check Valves:** N1 and N2. - **Temperature Controller (TC):** A controller near valve V3. **Flow Paths:** - The refrigerant cycle is depicted with black lines for high-pressure vapor, red lines for high-pressure liquid/vapor, blue lines for low-pressure liquid/vapor, and green lines for intermediate stages, often indicating a liquid line. - The heat exchanger H has separate red and blue lines indicating a secondary fluid loop, possibly for heating or cooling a process fluid. **Overall Operation:** The diagram illustrates a typical vapor-compression refrigeration cycle modified with a heat exchanger, likely for heat recovery or a specific application where both cooling and heating are involved. The caption indicates it's a demo cooling installation.::> Koelen Figuur 3 Schema van demo-koelinstallatie (koelen)

Beschrijving<::A laboratory setup of a refrigeration cycle model is shown on a white table. The model features transparent sections, allowing visibility of the internal components and fluid flow. On the left, a compressor unit is visible, connected via pipes to two large vertical panels mounted on a white backboard. The left panel displays a clear serpentine tube with circular openings at the bottom, suggesting an evaporator. The right panel also features a clear serpentine tube, likely representing a condenser. Various gauges, valves, and smaller components are interconnected by copper piping across the table, illustrating the complete refrigeration system. A small fan-cooled condenser unit is also visible on the right side of the table.Figuur 1 Glazen model: photo::>

<::A screenshot from a video showing a man pointing to a scientific or industrial apparatus. The apparatus features two rectangular units with clear front panels, revealing internal transparent tubing arranged horizontally. Copper pipes connect the units, and gauges are visible at the bottom. The man, wearing glasses and a dark shirt, is explaining the model. A video player overlay is present at the bottom, indicating 0:13 / 1:06. Figure 2 Explanation of glass model : video screenshot::>

Opgaven bij het schema<::A schematic diagram of a refrigeration or heat pump system.The main components are:- H: Evaporator (blue coiled heat exchanger) with connections C0 and C1.- I: Condenser (red coiled heat exchanger) with connection M2.- S: Compressor, connected to C2 on the suction side and M1 on the discharge side.- F: Thermostatic Expansion Valve (TEV).- L: Liquid receiver.- E: Filter drier.- D: Sight glass or liquid indicator.- K: Control unit with labels LD (Low Discharge) and HD (High Discharge), connected to the compressor discharge line and M2.- R: Condenser fan unit, connected after the condenser I.- G: Shut-off valve.Pressure gauges (PI) are labeled A and B. A pressure control (PC) is labeled P.Flow path:- The compressor (S) draws refrigerant from C2 (evaporator outlet) and discharges to M1.- M1 connects to K, then to M2.- M2 feeds the condenser (I).- From condenser (I), refrigerant goes to the condenser fan unit (R).- From R, it passes through pressure control P and enters the liquid receiver (L).- From L, the refrigerant flows through O, then filter drier (E), then valve (G), and then sight glass (D).- From D, it passes through the thermostatic expansion valve (F).- The expanded refrigerant enters the evaporator (H) at C0.- From evaporator (H), it exits at C1, which loops back to M2 and also connects to C0, eventually returning to the compressor (S) via C2.Pressure gauge A is connected to the line before the TEV (F). Pressure gauge B is connected to the line after the sight glass (D) and before the TEV (F).: diagram::>Figuur 3 Schema glazenmodel7. Wat is in het schema de verdamper?8. Wat is in dit schema de condensor?9. Wat is in dit schema het expansieorgaan?

Koelkringloop-proces<::A schematic diagram illustrating a refrigeration cycle, labeled "Schema glazenmodel" (Glass model scheme). The cycle includes the following components: - H: An evaporator, depicted as blue coils, connected to points C0 and C1. - I: A condenser, depicted as red coils, connected to point M2. - S: A compressor, located at the bottom left, with connections C2 and M1. - A: A pressure indicator (PI) on the line between the compressor (S) and the evaporator (H). - F: A thermostatic expansion valve (TEV) on the line between the compressor (S) and the evaporator (H). - B: A pressure indicator (PI) on the line between the compressor (S) and the condenser (I). - K: A control unit or component with connections labeled LD (Low Differential) and HD (High Differential), situated on the line from the compressor to the condenser. - R: A fan/heat exchanger unit, positioned after the condenser (I). - P: A pressure control (PC) sensor, located after the fan/heat exchanger (R). - L: A receiver tank, positioned after the pressure control (P). - O: A pipe connecting the receiver (L) to a filter. - E: A filter/drier unit. - G: A valve. - D: A sight glass, located before the thermostatic expansion valve (F). The refrigerant flows from the compressor (S) to the condenser (I), then through the receiver (L), filter (E), valve (G), sight glass (D), and expansion valve (F) to the evaporator (H), and finally back to the compressor (S). Figuur 4 Schema glazenmodel::>

<::diagram: The image displays a refrigeration cycle (koelkringloop) with its main components and the corresponding P-h diagram. The cycle starts from the evaporator (bottom, blue tubing with internal arrows indicating flow to the right), where the refrigerant absorbs heat, represented by fans blowing over the coils. The refrigerant then flows as a low-pressure vapor (light blue pipe) to the compressor (right, green and red engine-like component with a piston). From the compressor, the high-pressure, high-temperature vapor (red pipe with arrows indicating flow upwards and to the left) moves to the condenser (top, red tubing with internal arrows indicating flow to the left), where it releases heat to the surroundings, again represented by fans. After condensing, the high-pressure liquid refrigerant (yellow pipe with arrows indicating flow to the left and downwards) goes to the expansion valve (left, a mechanical component with yellow and dark blue inlets/outlets). The expansion valve reduces the pressure and temperature of the refrigerant (dark blue pipe with arrows indicating flow to the right), which then returns to the evaporator to complete the cycle. The diagram also includes numbered boxes at various points in the cycle: 1, 2, 3, 4, 5, 6, which likely denote specific states or measurement points. In the center of the diagram, a P-h (Pressure-enthalpy) chart illustrates the thermodynamic states of the refrigerant throughout the cycle, showing a typical refrigeration cycle loop within the saturation dome, with pressure (P) on the y-axis and enthalpy (h) on the x-axis. Figuur 9 De koelkringloop::>

ROVC Technisch de beste opleider koeltechniek <::figure: The image displays a detailed diagram of a refrigeration cycle. On the left side, there is a menu with the ROVC logo and the text "Technisch de beste opleider". Below the logo, a vertical menu bar contains a hamburger icon at the top, followed by a prominent blue button labeled "Start". Other menu items, which appear inactive, include "Koelen", "Vriezen", and "Koelen met diagram". Below these, there are three small square icons, two of which are highlighted. On the right side of the image, window controls (speaker, minimize, maximize, close) are visible. The central part of the image is dominated by the refrigeration cycle diagram. The diagram illustrates a compressor (green and grey component on the right), a condenser (red coiled pipes with fans at the top), an expansion valve (yellow component on the left), and an evaporator (blue coiled pipes with fans at the bottom). Arrows indicate the direction of refrigerant flow. Several numbered labels provide temperature and pressure readings at different points in the cycle: Label 4 shows 55°C and 9 bar. Label 5 shows 40°C and 9 bar. Label 6 shows 35°C and 9 bar. Label 1 shows -5°C and 1.4 bar. Label 2 shows -5°C and 1.4 bar. Label 3 shows 0°C and 1.4 bar. An additional label indicates the refrigerant type as R134a.::>

<::diagram: The diagram illustrates the processes of evaporation and condensation. At the top, a blue kettle with a red handle and spout is shown, emitting steam, symbolizing the transition from liquid to gas. Below this, a flow shows two states: "Vloeistof" (Liquid) in a blue rectangular box on the left, and "Gas" in a gray rectangular box on the right. An orange and red arrow points from "Vloeistof" to "Gas", labeled "Verdampen (verwarmen)" (Evaporation (heating)). A blue arrow points from "Gas" to "Vloeistof", labeled "Condenseren (afkoelen)" (Condensation (cooling)). Below these arrows, a rectangular image displays a surface covered with numerous water droplets, visually representing condensation. Figuur 11 Verdampen en condenseren::>

<::chart: A phase diagram for water at 1 bar absolute pressure. The vertical axis is 'Temperatuur' (Temperature) in °C, and the horizontal axis is 'Warmtetoevoer' (Heat supply). The graph shows four points labeled A, B, C, and D. Point A is at 0 °C. From A to B, the temperature increases from 0 °C to 100 °C, representing the heating of liquid water. This section is associated with 'Verwarmen van de vloeistof' (Heating of the liquid). Point B is at 100 °C. From B to C, the temperature remains constant at 100 °C while heat is added, indicating the 'Verdampingsproces' (Evaporation process) where water changes from liquid to vapor. Point C is at 100 °C. From C to D, the temperature of the vapor increases above 100 °C. This section is associated with 'Verwarmen van de damp' (Heating of the vapor). The diagram specifies 'H₂O (water)' and 'Druk = 1 bara'.::>Figuur 14 Verdampingsproces van water

<::chart: A graph titled "Condensatieproces van water" (Condensation process of water) shows temperature versus heat dissipation. The y-axis is labeled "Temperatuur" (Temperature) with values 0 °C and 100 °C. The x-axis is labeled "Warmteafvoer" (Heat dissipation). The graph shows a process from point A to D. From point A (0 °C) to B (100 °C), there is an upward sloping line representing the heating of water, indicated by a gradient arrow. From point B to C (both at 100 °C), there is a horizontal line labeled "Condensatieproces" (Condensation process), representing the phase change from vapor to liquid at a constant temperature. This segment is also labeled on the right as "Condensatie van de vloeistof" (Condensation of the liquid). From point C to D, there is an upward sloping line representing the cooling of the vapor. This segment is labeled on the right as "Afkoelen van de damp" (Cooling of the vapor). In the top right corner, a box contains the text "H₂O (water)" and "Druk = 1 barᵃ" (Pressure = 1 barᵃ).::>

<::chart: The chart, titled "Figuur 18 Verband tussen verdampingstemperatuur en warmte-inhoud bij een druk van 1 bara", displays the relationship between evaporation temperature and heat content at a pressure of 1 bar. The y-axis is labeled "Temperatuur °C" with tick marks at 100, 0, -26, -30, -33, -34, -41, -46, -48, and -53. The x-axis is labeled "Warmte-inhoud kJ/kg". Multiple lines represent different substances, each showing an initial increase in temperature with heat content, followed by a plateau (indicating phase change), and then a further increase in temperature. The legend identifies the substances and their corresponding line styles/colors: Water/stoom (solid light blue line), R-134a (solid purple line), R-1234yf (dashed teal line), NH3 (solid yellow line), R-407C (solid dark blue line), R404a (dashed orange line), R-507 (solid red line), and R-32 (solid brown line).::>

<::diagram: refrigeration cycle::>A diagram illustrating a refrigeration cycle with components including a compressor, condenser, expansion valve, and evaporator, showing the flow of refrigerant and its conditions at various points.The cycle begins with the compressor on the right. Hot, high-pressure gas exits the compressor and flows into the condenser (top, red pipes). In the condenser, the refrigerant cools and condenses. At point 4, the temperature is 55°C and pressure is 9 bar. At point 5, after some cooling, the refrigerant is at 40°C and 9 bar. The section between point 5 and point 6 is labeled "Onderkoeling vloeistof" (Subcooling liquid), where the refrigerant is further cooled to 35°C at 9 bar (point 6), indicating it is subcooled liquid.From point 6, the subcooled liquid refrigerant flows through a yellow pipe to the expansion valve (left side). After passing through the expansion valve, the refrigerant's temperature and pressure drop significantly.At point 1, the refrigerant is at -5°C and 1.4 bar. It then enters the evaporator (bottom, blue pipes). In the evaporator, the refrigerant absorbs heat and evaporates. At point 2, the refrigerant is still at -5°C and 1.4 bar. The section between point 2 and point 3 is labeled "Oververhitting zuiggas" (Superheating suction gas), indicating the refrigerant becomes superheated vapor. At point 3, the refrigerant is at 0°C and 1.4 bar. An additional label near point 3 indicates "5°C R134a", possibly representing the superheated suction gas temperature entering the compressor, with R134a being the refrigerant type. The superheated gas then returns to the compressor to complete the cycle. The flow direction is indicated by arrows throughout the pipes.Figuur 19 Oververhitting zuiggas en onderkoeling vloeistof

<::h log p-diagram showing phase regions:The diagram plots pressure (p) on the y-axis against enthalpy (h) on the x-axis. A bell-shaped curve represents the phase envelope, with a critical point (k.p) at its peak. The region to the left of the curve is labeled 'vloeistof' (liquid). The region inside the curve is labeled 'vloeistof + damp' (liquid + vapor). The region to the right of the curve is labeled 'oververhit gas' (superheated gas). An arrow points to the left side of the curve, labeled 'vloeistoflijn' (liquid line). An arrow points to the right side of the curve, labeled 'verzadigde damplijn' (saturated vapor line).Figure 21 Basisindeling h log p-diagram::>

<::Three p-h diagrams are presented side-by-side. Each diagram has 'p' on the y-axis and 'h' on the x-axis, and features a black saturation dome. From the right side of the dome, a red curve and a blue curve extend downwards towards the h-axis. Below the diagrams, the caption reads: Figuur 22 Lijnen van constante druk en temperatuur. Left Diagram: - Two horizontal dashed lines are shown: a red line labeled 'pc' and a blue line labeled 'pv'. Middle Diagram: - Two horizontal solid lines are shown: a red line labeled 'pc' and a blue line labeled 'pv'. - Two vertical solid lines originate from the p-axis: a blue line labeled 'Tv' and a red line labeled 'Tc'. Right Diagram: - Two horizontal solid lines are shown: a red line labeled 'pc' with a dashed extension to the right, and a blue line labeled 'pv' with a dashed extension to the right. - Two vertical solid lines originate from the p-axis: a blue line labeled 'Tv' and a red line labeled 'Tc'. : chart::>

<::p-h diagram showing a phase envelope (black curve). The y-axis is labeled 'p' (pressure) in 'bara', with horizontal dashed lines at 2,9 bara (blue) and 7,7 bara (red). The x-axis is labeled 'h' (enthalpy) in 'kJ/kg', with vertical gray lines at 200, 241, and 397. A vertical blue line is labeled '0°' and a vertical red line is labeled '30°'. There is a blue vertical line extending from the x-axis, intersecting the 2,9 bara horizontal line and the phase envelope. There is also a red vertical line extending from the x-axis, intersecting the 7,7 bara horizontal line and the phase envelope. A point on the x-axis is labeled '413'. Figuur 23 Lijnen en waarden voor constante warmte-inhoud : chart::>

Expanderen en comprimeren <::p-h diagram showing compression and expansion processes : chart::> Figuur 24 Compressie en expansie The chart displays a pressure-enthalpy (p-h) diagram. The y-axis represents pressure (p) and the x-axis represents enthalpy (h) in kJ/kg. A saturation dome is depicted by a thick black curve. Inside the dome, there are two vertical lines representing isotherms: Tv (blue line) and Tc (red line). Two horizontal dashed lines represent isobars: pc (red) and pv (blue). Key points and processes indicated: - The Tv isotherm intersects the x-axis at approximately 200 kJ/kg and a point within the dome at approximately 397 kJ/kg. - The Tc isotherm intersects the x-axis at approximately 241 kJ/kg and a point within the dome at approximately 413 kJ/kg. - A dashed arrow points downwards from the intersection of the Tc isotherm and the pc isobar to the pv isobar, indicating a process from higher pressure/temperature to lower pressure. - On the right side of the dome, a red curve extends downwards to h = 418 kJ/kg. - Another dashed arrow points upwards from a point on the pv isobar within the dome to the red curve on the right, indicating a process from lower pressure to higher enthalpy. <::>

<::A diagram consisting of two main parts. The top part illustrates a pressure scale. A vertical line represents pressure 'p'. A horizontal dashed line at the center indicates 'atmosferische druk 1 barᵃ / 0 barᵉ / 100.000 Pascal'. Above this line, a black rectangle labeled 'overdruk' (overpressure) is shown, with a dashed line indicating '2 barᵃ' and '1 barᵉ'. Below the atmospheric pressure line, a black rectangle labeled 'onderdruk' (underpressure) is shown, with a dashed line indicating '0 barᵃ' and '-1 barᵉ / 0 Pascal'.The bottom part of the diagram depicts a cooling installation circuit. The circuit shows the flow of refrigerant (vloeistof/gas) through various components:1. A compressor (labeled '1' in a circle) receives 'vloeistof/gas' at 1.9 barᵉ (indicated by pressure sensor P). It is driven by 'Toegevoegde energie (warmte)'.2. The compressor outputs high-pressure 'gas' which passes a pressure sensor P and a temperature sensor T (labeled '4') reading 6.7 barᵉ and 43°C.3. This high-pressure gas then enters a condenser (labeled '5', depicted as a heat exchanger with a fan inside). The condenser has an internal temperature of +30°C and facilitates 'Warmteafvoer naar omgeving +15°C' (heat dissipation to ambient +15°C).4. The refrigerant exits the condenser as 'vloeistof' (liquid) and passes a temperature sensor T and a pressure sensor P (labeled '6') reading 25°C and 6.7 barᵉ.5. The liquid then passes through an expansion device (not explicitly numbered but implied in the circuit).6. After expansion, the refrigerant (now 'gas') passes a pressure sensor P and a temperature sensor T (labeled '3') reading 1.9 barᵉ and +5°C.7. This low-pressure refrigerant then enters an evaporator (labeled '2', depicted as a heat exchanger with a fan inside, enclosed in a dashed box representing 'Ruimte +8°C'). The evaporator has an internal temperature of -0°C and receives 'Warmtetoevoer' (heat supply).8. The refrigerant exits the evaporator and returns to the compressor, completing the cycle.: diagram::>Figuur 25 Meetwaarden bij een koelinstallatie

10. Bereken op basis van de gegevens ook de oververhitting en onderkoeling. Noteer deze ook in het meetrapport. <::A pressure-enthalpy (p-h) diagram illustrating a refrigeration cycle. The y-axis represents pressure (p) and the x-axis represents enthalpy (h). A black saturation dome defines the two-phase region. Two dashed horizontal lines indicate pressure levels: 2.9 bara and 7.7 bara. Several isotherms are shown: blue lines are labeled 0°, 5°, 25°, 30°, and a red line is labeled 43°C. The refrigeration cycle is depicted by a series of numbered points and colored arrows: 1, 2, 3, 4, 5, 6. The cycle starts from point 1 at 2.9 bara, moves horizontally to point 2 (evaporation), then follows an angled path (compression) through point 3 to point 4 at 43°C and 7.7 bara. From point 4, it moves horizontally to point 5 (condensation) at 7.7 bara, then vertically downwards to point 6 (subcooling/expansion), and finally vertically from point 6 back to point 1 (expansion/throttling) at 2.9 bara. The arrows indicate the direction of the cycle: green arrows for evaporation (1 to 2), compression (2 to 6, then to 5, then to 4), and expansion (6 to 1); red arrows for condensation (4 to 5). The path from point 2 to 6 is a vertical line up to the 7.7 bara line, then horizontally to point 5, then point 4. There's a vertical line from point 6 down to point 1. The sequence of processes appears to be: evaporation (1-2), compression (2-3-4), condensation (4-5), expansion/subcooling (5-6), and throttling (6-1). : diagram::> Figuur 4 Meetgegevens (p en T) in vereenvoudigd diagram

<::A diagram titled "Koelinstallatie met hulpcomponenten" (Refrigeration installation with auxiliary components) shows the components of a refrigeration system arranged in a cycle with red arrows indicating the flow. The cycle begins with a compressor, which leads to a hogedrukbeveiliging (high-pressure protection device). From there, the flow goes to a condensor (condenser), then to a vloeistofreservoir (liquid reservoir). Next in the cycle is a filter-droger (filter-dryer), followed by a vloeistof kijkglas (liquid sight glass), and then an elektromagneet afsluiter (solenoid valve). The flow continues to an expansieorgaan (expansion device), which leads to a verdamper (evaporator). Finally, the verdamper connects to a lagedrukbeveiliging (low-pressure protection device), which returns the flow to the compressor, completing the cycle. : diagram::> Figuur 35 Koelinstallatie met hulpcomponenten

<:: Piping and Instrumentation Diagram (P&ID) showing a process system. The diagram illustrates a process involving multiple cooling units, a separation or condensation vessel, and parallel pumping/compression stages. The flow direction is generally from left to right and top to bottom. 1. **Left Section - Parallel Cooling Units:** - Four identical parallel cooling circuits are shown. - Each circuit includes a fan-driven heat exchanger (cooler) with a fan symbol. - A Temperature Controller (TC) is shown on the outlet of each cooler, controlling a valve on that line. - The inlets of these four units are fed from a common manifold. - The outlets of these four units merge into another common manifold. - Process lines associated with these units also show Temperature Indicators (TI) and Temperature Controllers (TC). 2. **Top Right Section - Separation/Condensation and Associated Equipment:** - A vertical column with a top vent or sensor connection is shown, leading to a vertical flow indicator. - This connects to a horizontal vessel (possibly a separator or accumulator) with an internal component (e.g., demister or level sensor). - A line from this vessel leads to a control valve assembly consisting of two control valves with a bypass and what appears to be a pressure relief valve arrangement. - Another fan-driven heat exchanger (cooler) is connected, with a Pressure Transmitter (PT) and a Flow Recorder (FR) associated with its outlet. - A line from the horizontal vessel also feeds into a smaller vessel (possibly a knockout drum or collection tank) before flowing to the next stage. 3. **Bottom Right Section - Parallel Pumping/Compression Units:** - Two identical parallel units are depicted, each representing a pump or compressor (circular symbol with two internal dots) with associated wavy lines indicating heat exchange or a specific pump type. - Each unit has extensive instrumentation: - Multiple Pressure Indicators (PI) on the inlet and outlet lines. - A Pressure Element (PE) and a High (H) alarm/indicator on a side line. - A Pressure Difference Controller (PDC) associated with the unit. - A Motor (M) driving the unit. - A Flow Recorder (FR) on the discharge line. - The inlets to these two units are fed from a common manifold (from the smaller vessel in the top right section). - The outlets of these two units combine into a final common manifold. ::>

<::pressure-enthalpy diagram::> This diagram illustrates the use of a heat exchanger to prevent flash gas. It shows a thermodynamic cycle on a pressure-enthalpy chart with a saturation dome. <::Process and Instrumentation Diagram (P&ID)::> The diagram depicts a process system with three parallel cooling or conditioning units (A, B, C) feeding into a common header, which then leads to a larger processing section. **Left Side (Units A, B, C):** Each unit (A, B, C) consists of: - A rectangular heat exchanger or cooler with an internal fan/impeller symbol. - An inlet line with a manual shut-off valve (gate valve symbol) and a check valve. - An outlet line with a manual shut-off valve. - A bypass line around the heat exchanger, containing a manual shut-off valve and a check valve. - A control loop with a Temperature Controller (TC) connected to a control valve on the inlet of the heat exchanger. - All three units' main process lines converge into a common header running vertically on the left side of the diagram. **Right Side (Main Processing Section):** - The common header from the left connects to a main process line that feeds into a large vertical cylindrical vessel (tank/separator). - A pump is located at the bottom outlet of the vessel. - The pump discharges into a line that splits: - One path goes through a control valve regulated by a Pressure Controller (PC) (indicated by a dashed line connection). - Another path leads to a main temperature control section: - A temperature sensor (T) inside a circular instrument bubble, connected to a motor (M) actuator (indicated by '~3' symbol for 3-phase motor) which operates a control valve. - A bypass line around this temperature control valve, containing a check valve. - Downstream from the temperature control section, the line passes through: - A flow meter (represented by an orifice plate symbol with differential pressure taps). - A component, possibly a filter or strainer. - A level indicator (vertical bar with 'H' for high and 'L' for low level indications). - The final outlet line has a manual valve (indicated by 'H' for hand valve) and a control valve. **Valve Legend:** - `open`: [Symbol of an open valve (wedge not touching)] - `dicht`: [Symbol of a closed valve (wedge touching)]

<:: : P&ID Diagram: The diagram illustrates a process flow with three parallel cooling/heating units (A, B, C) connected to a main system comprising a vessel, pump, and additional heat exchange components. **Legend:** - open: [Symbol of an open manual valve] - dicht: [Symbol of a closed manual valve] **System Overview:** **1. Parallel Units (A, B, C):** Each unit (A, B, C) is identical and contains: - A rectangular box labeled 'A', 'B', or 'C'. - Inside each box: A heat exchanger with a fan/impeller (indicating forced convection, likely an air-cooled heat exchanger or condenser). - **Inlet Line to each unit:** Features a manual valve (with a square actuator symbol) followed by a non-return valve, then another manual valve, leading into the heat exchanger. - **Outlet Line from each unit:** Features a control valve connected to a Temperature Controller (TC). This line merges back into a common header. - **Bypass Line around each heat exchanger:** Contains a manual valve (with a square actuator symbol). - **Drain/Vent points:** Small manual valves are present at various points on the lines connecting to units A, B, and C. **2. Main System Components (Right Side):** - **Main Inlet Header:** The common header from units A, B, C, flows into the main system. - **Vessel:** A large vertical cylindrical vessel (tank/receiver). - **Vessel Inlet:** A line leading to the vessel's top, featuring a manual valve, then a control valve connected to a Pressure Controller (PC). A dashed line indicates the PC's control action on the valve. - **Vessel Outlet (Bottom):** - One outlet line has a pump, followed by a flow indicator, then a manual valve. - Another outlet line has a manual valve and a level indicator (with a float symbol). - **Heat Exchanger (Right Side):** Another heat exchanger with a fan/impeller, similar to those in units A, B, C, is connected to a line feeding into the vessel. This line also includes a manual valve. - **Main Outlet Line (from vessel top):** A line from the top of the vessel connects to a main return line. This line includes a manual valve, followed by a control valve labeled 'T' (Temperature) with a '3~ M' (3-phase Motorized) actuator, and another manual valve. - **Flow Meter/Sensor:** A circular component with an internal dot and horizontal lines, possibly a flow meter or sensor, is located on the main return line after the vessel outlet. **Connections:** - All major process lines are solid lines. - Control signals are represented by dashed lines (e.g., from PC to valve). - Manual valves are represented by various symbols, including simple butterfly valves and square-actuated valves. - Non-return valves are present in the inlet lines to units A, B, C. ::>

<::A detailed diagram illustrating a refrigeration cycle and its corresponding pressure-enthalpy (P-h) diagram. The refrigeration cycle shows the flow of refrigerant through various components: a compressor (right, green/red), a condenser (top, red/yellow coils with a fan), an expansion valve (left, yellow/blue), and an evaporator (bottom, blue/light blue coils with a fan). Arrows indicate the direction of refrigerant flow, and color changes represent different states and temperatures. The cycle begins with the compressor (red/light blue) discharging high-pressure, high-temperature gaseous refrigerant (red pipe, point 4). This refrigerant flows to the condenser (top), where it releases heat (indicated by the fan) and condenses into a high-pressure liquid (yellow pipe, point 5). The liquid then passes through an expansion valve (left), where its pressure and temperature drop significantly (blue pipe, point 6). This low-pressure, low-temperature refrigerant then enters the evaporator (bottom), absorbs heat (indicated by the fan) and evaporates into a low-pressure gas (light blue pipe, point 1). This gaseous refrigerant then returns to the compressor to complete the cycle. Points 2 and 3 are also marked along the evaporator exit and inlet to the compressor respectively. The central P-h diagram plots pressure (P) against enthalpy (h), showing the thermodynamic states of the refrigerant throughout the cycle. It features a saturation dome and a closed loop connecting four colored points (red, yellow, light blue, blue) that correspond to the states of the refrigerant at different stages of the cycle, matching the colors used in the main diagram. The diagram illustrates the compression, condensation, expansion, and evaporation processes on the P-h chart.: diagram::>Figuur 4

<::diagram: A schematic diagram of a cooling installation with hot gas defrosting. The diagram illustrates three evaporators, labeled A, B, and C, arranged vertically. Each evaporator includes a fan symbol and is connected to a thermal expansion valve (TC). A main liquid line supplies refrigerant to valves 1, 5, and 9, which control flow to evaporators A, B, and C respectively. The outlets of the evaporators connect to valves 3, 7, and 11, leading to a common suction line. Hot gas defrosting lines are also shown. A hot gas line, originating from the compressor (indicated by 'M' for motor and 'T' for temperature), feeds hot gas through valve 10 to the inlets of the evaporators (before valves 1, 5, 9) via check valves (2, 6). Additionally, another hot gas line goes through a pressure control valve (PC, labeled 13) and connects to valves 4, 8, and 12, which are parallel to the main outlet valves 3, 7, and 11 respectively, allowing hot gas into the evaporator outlets for defrosting. The system also includes a condenser, a receiver tank, a filter/drier, and a sight glass in the liquid line. A legend indicates symbols for an "open" valve and a "dicht" (closed) valve. Figuur 1 Schema van koelinstallatie met heetgasontdooiing::>

Another pressure point "pU" is indicated near the bulb. An outlet pipe from the valve is labeled "naar compressor". The serpentine coil is shown with a pressure drop "ΔP" across it. De regeling van het ventiel werkt dus op basis van een evenwicht tussen de veerdruk + de verdamperdruk en de druk van de bulb. <::diagram of forces acting on a membrane, illustrating the equilibrium of pressures on an expansion valve diaphragm. To the right of the membrane, a vertical double-headed arrow indicates "sluiten" (close) for the upward direction and "openen" (open) for the downward direction. A legend box provides definitions for the pressures: pB = druk in bulb (pressure in bulb) pS = veerdruk (spring pressure) pV = verdampingsdruk (evaporation pressure) : diagram::> Figuur 98 Evenwicht van drukken op het membraan van het expansieventiel (inwendige drukvereffening)

Inside the valve, there's a "membraan" (membrane) at the top, and below it, a spring labeled "veerdruk Ps" (spring pressure Ps). A "stelschroef veerspanning" (adjustment screw spring tension) is on the side, controlling the spring. At the bottom, an inlet is labeled "van vloeistofreservoir" (from liquid reservoir), leading to a conical valve seat. The main outlet from the valve body is labeled "pV" and connects to a series of four horizontal coiled pipes, representing an evaporator. A double-headed arrow on the right side of the coiled pipes indicates a pressure difference, labeled "ΔP".: figure::> Figuur 99 Principe tekening van een expansieventiel met uitwendige drukvereffening

<::diagram: A horizontal line represents a membrane. An arrow labeled "pB" points downwards onto the right side of the membrane. <::diagram: A process and instrumentation diagram (P&ID) illustrating an indirect pressure-controlled evaporator pressure regulator within a refrigeration or HVAC system. The diagram shows two evaporator/condenser units, a compressor, a receiver tank, and several control valves and instruments. Starting from the left: 1. A rectangular unit with a fan and upward arrows (evaporator/condenser 1) receives flow from a lower line and outputs to a horizontal line. 2. On this horizontal line, there's a valve labeled "Verdamperdrukregelaar" (Evaporator Pressure Regulator). 3. In parallel to the "Verdamperdrukregelaar" valve, there's another valve controlled by a Pressure Controller (PC). The PC senses pressure from the line after the "Verdamperdrukregelaar" valve. 4. The combined flow from these valves proceeds to a compressor, represented by a circular symbol with a triangle inside. The compressor has two pressure indicators: PE-L (Low Pressure) and PE-H (High Pressure). 5. The output of the compressor goes to a second rectangular unit with a fan and downward arrows (evaporator/condenser 2). 6. The output of evaporator/condenser 2 flows into a receiver tank, depicted as an elongated horizontal oval. 7. From the receiver tank, a line leads to a valve controlled by a Temperature Controller (TC). 8. The output of the TC-controlled valve then connects back to the input line of the first evaporator/condenser unit, completing the loop. Figure 111 Indirect drukgestuurde verdamperdrukregelaar::>

<::Schematic diagram: The diagram illustrates an indirect pressure-controlled evaporator pressure regulator system designed for two different temperatures. It features two evaporators, each equipped with a fan and heat exchange elements. The outlet line from the left evaporator passes through a valve controlled by a PC HD (Pressure Controller High Discharge) unit. The outlet line from the right evaporator connects to the low-pressure side (labeled PE L) of a compressor. The compressor's high-pressure side (labeled PE H) outputs to a main line, which also has a bypass line. This bypass line contains a valve controlled by a PC LD (Pressure Controller Low Discharge) unit. Additionally, a branch line from the left evaporator's circuit goes through a valve controlled by a TC (Temperature Controller) and then leads to a receiver/accumulator, which is further connected back into the main liquid line. The system components are interconnected by pipes, indicating the flow of refrigerant.::>Figuur 112 Indirect drukgestuurde verdamperdrukregelaar voor twee temperaturen

Temperatuurgestuurde verdamperdrukregelaars <::diagram: A schematic diagram of a refrigeration system. On the left, an evaporator unit is shown with a fan and upward arrows indicating airflow. The outlet of the evaporator connects to a pipe that splits. One path goes through a valve controlled by a pressure controller (PC) and then to the inlet of a compressor. The other path from the evaporator outlet goes through a valve controlled by a temperature controller (TC) and then rejoins the main line before the compressor. The compressor is depicted as a circular unit with two pressure indicators (PE L and PE H) connected to its inlet and outlet respectively. The outlet of the compressor connects to a condenser unit, shown on the right, with a fan and downward arrows indicating airflow. The outlet of the condenser connects to a receiver tank, depicted as a horizontal oval. The outlet of the receiver tank connects back to the inlet of the evaporator, completing the loop. Figuur 113 Direct werkende temperatuurgestuurde verdamperdrukregelaar ::>

<::Schematic diagram of a refrigeration system titled "Indirect werkende temperatuurgestuurde verdamperdrukregelaar" (Indirectly operating temperature-controlled evaporator pressure regulator). The diagram shows a closed-loop system with the following components: - On the left, an evaporator unit with a fan (propeller symbol) and upward-pointing arrows indicating airflow. Refrigerant enters from the bottom right and exits from the top left. - On the right, a condenser unit with a fan (propeller symbol) and downward-pointing arrows indicating airflow. Refrigerant enters from the top left and exits from the bottom right. - A compressor, represented by a circular symbol with a triangular internal component, is located between the evaporator and condenser. It has two pressure elements (PE) connected, one labeled 'L' (low pressure) and the other 'H' (high pressure). - A thermostatic expansion valve (valve symbol with 'TC' - Temperature Controller) is located on the high-pressure liquid line, before the evaporator. - A shut-off or service valve is located downstream of the thermostatic expansion valve. - An evaporator pressure regulator (another valve symbol with 'TC' - Temperature Controller) is located on the suction line after the evaporator, regulating flow to a receiver. - A receiver, represented by a horizontal cylindrical tank, is located after the evaporator pressure regulator and before the compressor suction. The piping connects these components in a continuous loop, illustrating the flow of refrigerant through the system. : diagram::> **Figuur 114** Indirect werkende temperatuurgestuurde verdamperdrukregelaar

<::diagram: A process and instrumentation diagram (P&ID) illustrating a combined pressure- and temperature-controlled indirect evaporator pressure regulator system.The diagram shows two main evaporators, each equipped with a fan for air circulation. The left evaporator has fluid entering from the bottom and exiting from the top. The right evaporator has fluid entering from the top and exiting from the bottom.A pump is situated in the main flow path, drawing fluid from the outlet of the left evaporator and supplying it to the inlet of the right evaporator. This pump is instrumented with two pressure elements (PE), one for low pressure ('L') and one for high pressure ('H').After the right evaporator, the fluid flows into a receiver or accumulator before returning to the inlet of the left evaporator, completing the main loop.Control mechanisms are integrated throughout the system:1. A pressure controller (PC) is connected to a control valve. This valve is part of a bypass line that diverts flow from the main line after the left evaporator, and rejoins the main line before the pump. An additional manual valve and another valve are shown in parallel within this control section.2. A temperature controller (TC) is connected to a control valve located on a line that branches from the main flow path after the left evaporator and merges back before the pump, influencing the flow to the pump.3. A second temperature controller (TC) is connected to a control valve on a bypass line that originates from the return line from the receiver and connects to the line leading to the pump, effectively bypassing the left evaporator for a portion of the flow.Figuur 115 Gecombineerde uitvoering druk- en temperatuurgestuurde indirect werkende verdamperdruk-regelaar::>

<::transcription of the content: diagram::A schematic diagram illustrating a multiple-evaporator refrigeration system with different evaporator temperatures.The system consists of three distinct refrigeration circuits, each operating at a different temperature, connected to a common liquid supply and suction line.1. **Liquid Supply Side:** * A main "Vloeistof" (liquid) line feeds into a horizontal heat exchanger (coil symbol). * The output of the heat exchanger connects to a "Vloeistof-verdeelbuis" (liquid distribution pipe). * From the distribution pipe, separate lines lead to each of the three evaporator circuits.2. **Evaporator Circuits (from top to bottom):** * **Top Circuit:** Enclosed in a dashed blue box. * An expansion valve (represented by a valve symbol with an angled line) is followed by a temperature controller (TC). * This feeds into an evaporator unit labeled "-10°C", depicted as a rectangular box containing a fan symbol and upward arrows indicating airflow. * The outlet of this evaporator connects to the common suction line. * **Middle Circuit:** Enclosed in a dashed blue box. * An expansion valve is followed by a temperature controller (TC). * This feeds into an evaporator unit labeled "-5°C", depicted as a rectangular box containing a fan symbol and upward arrows indicating airflow. * The outlet of this evaporator passes through a pressure indicator (PI) and a pressure controller (PC) before connecting to the common suction line. * **Bottom Circuit:** Enclosed in a dashed blue box. * An expansion valve is followed by a temperature controller (TC). * This feeds into an evaporator unit labeled "0°C", depicted as a rectangular box containing a fan symbol and upward arrows indicating airflow. * The outlet of this evaporator passes through a pressure indicator (PI) and a pressure controller (PC) before connecting to the common suction line.3. **Suction Line:** * All three evaporator circuits converge into a common "Zuig" (suction) line.Figuur 116 Schema meervoudig systeem met verschillende verdampertemperaturen::>

<::A detailed photograph of a water control valve (Waterregelklep). The valve features a gray, ribbed adjustment knob at the top. <::Schematic diagram of a refrigeration or HVAC system. The system includes two heat exchangers with fans. The left heat exchanger has arrows pointing upwards into it, suggesting an evaporator, and is controlled by a TC (Temperature Controller) connected to a control valve. The right heat exchanger has arrows pointing downwards into it, suggesting a condenser. Between the two heat exchangers, there is a compressor. On the suction side of the compressor, there is a PC (Pressure Controller) connected to a control valve labeled "zuigdrukregelaar" (suction pressure regulator). <::A process and instrumentation diagram (P&ID) illustrates an indirectly acting start-pressure regulator system. The diagram shows two main heat exchanger units, each with a fan. Starting from the left unit, the pipeline goes through a U-shaped section, then proceeds horizontally. Along this horizontal line, there is a main valve, which is bypassed by a parallel line containing another valve. This bypass valve is controlled by a Pressure Controller (PC), which itself is connected to the main line, forming a pressure regulation loop. After this, the line feeds into a compressor or pump unit, indicated by a circle with an internal triangle. Pressure elements (PE) for low (L) and high (H) pressure are connected to the compressor unit. From the compressor, the line continues to the right heat exchanger unit. The outlet of the right unit connects to a horizontal cylindrical receiver tank. From the receiver, the pipeline returns to the U-shaped section of the left unit. Additionally, there is a bypass line branching off from the main return line (before the left unit). This bypass line contains a valve controlled by a Temperature Controller (TC). The TC itself is connected to the main return line and also has a sensing line from the main high-pressure line (before the PC-controlled bypass). The TC loop likely serves for temperature or hot gas bypass control.::>Figuur 131 Indirect werkende startdrukregelaar
